lead_paragraph: For Catherine McDougall, the case showed the lengths that Western firms will go to keep a potentially lucrative client happy and the damage left behind.

headline.print_headline: Fight Between Goldman and Libyan Fund Shadows Lawyer
headline.main: Fight Between Goldman Sachs and Libyan Fund Shadows Lawyer

snippet: For Catherine McDougall, the case showed the lengths that Western firms will go to keep a potentially lucrative client happy and the damage left behind....
abstract: Australian attorney Catherine McDougall, who was sent to Libya in 2008 by London law firm Allen & Overy, continues to be haunted by disciplinary proceeding against her, based on complaint from Libyan general counsel, that led to her resignation; now pulled in as witness in battle between Goldman Sachs and sovereign wealth fund Libyan Investment Authority, McDougall says her situation illustrates how much collateral damage  Western firms are willing to create in effort to keep potentially lucrative foreign clients content.
